article_text:
Moreover, Romney seems to be praising Obamacare's effects of dramatically reducing the nation's uninsured rate.

Romney's much-belated concession came in comments he made to the Boston Globe about the death Friday of his friend Thomas Stemberg, the founder of Staples, the office supply giant that was founded with backing from Bain Capital, Romney's former investment firm.



Romney told the Globe that soon after he was elected governor in late 2002, Stemberg asked him why he had run. When Romney said he did so to help people, "Stemberg replied that if he really wanted to help, he should give everyone access to health care, which Romney said he hadn't really considered before," the Globe article said.

"Without Tom pushing it, I don't think we would have had Romneycare," Romney told the Globe. "Without Romneycare, I don't think we would have Obamacare. So, without Tom a lot of people wouldn't have health insurance."

article_metadata.description: Mitt Romney said he wanted to kill Obamacare. Now thinks his own state-based health-care law led to that national program.
article_metadata.author: Dan Mangan

og.description: Mitt Romney once campaigned on a pledge to kill Obamacare. Now he lauds that law's effects.
og.title: Mitt Romney admits Romneycare led to Obamacare

twitter.description: Mitt Romney once campaigned on a pledge to kill Obamacare. Now he lauds that law's effects.
twitter.title: Romney: Obamacare grew out of Romneycare
twitter.creator: @_DanMangan

article_metadata.keywords: Health Care, Health Care, Obamacare, US: News, Politics, Staples Inc, business news
article_metadata.news_keywords: Obamacare, Mitt Romney, Barack Obama, Romneycare

article_summary:
"Without Tom pushing it, I don't think we would have had Romneycare," Romney told the Globe.
"Without Romneycare, I don't think we would have Obamacare.
Romney told the Globe that soon after he was elected governor in late 2002, Stemberg asked him why he had run.
Moreover, Romney seems to be praising Obamacare's effects of dramatically reducing the nation's uninsured rate.
So, without Tom a lot of people wouldn't have health insurance."
